trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET web project in Visual Studio 2013 and deploy it to a web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET web project in Visual Studio 2013 and deploy it to a web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to create an ASP.NET web application and deploy it to a [web app in Azure App Service](app-service-web-overview.md) by using Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to create an ASP.NET web application and deploy it to a [web app in Azure App Service](app-service-web-overview.md) by using Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience with using Azure or ASP.NET.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience with using Azure or ASP.NET.

trans-unit.source: On completing the tutorial, you'll have a simple web application up and running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: On completing the tutorial, you'll have a simple web application up and running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows the completed application:
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows the completed application:

trans-unit.source: Web app home page
trans-unit.target: Web app home page

trans-unit.source: You'll learn:
trans-unit.target: You'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Visual Studio ASP.NET web project and deploy it to an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Visual Studio ASP.NET web project and deploy it to an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: How to make a change to the web project and redeploy the application.
trans-unit.target: How to make a change to the web project and redeploy the application.

trans-unit.source: How to use the [Azure portal](/overview/preview-portal/) to monitor and manage your web app.
trans-unit.target: How to use the [Azure portal](/overview/preview-portal/) to monitor and manage your web app.

trans-unit.source: Sign up for Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Sign up for Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You can:
trans-unit.target: You can:

trans-unit.source: [Open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).
trans-unit.target: [Open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).

trans-unit.source: You get credits you that can use to try out paid Azure services.
trans-unit.target: You get credits you that can use to try out paid Azure services.

trans-unit.source: Even after the credits are used up, you can keep the account and use free Azure services and features, such as the Web Apps feature in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Even after the credits are used up, you can keep the account and use free Azure services and features, such as the Web Apps feature in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: [Activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).
trans-unit.target: [Activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).

trans-unit.source: Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.
trans-unit.target: Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751).

trans-unit.source: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.
trans-unit.target: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.

trans-unit.source: In this video, Scott Hanselman shows how easy it is to sign up for a free trial of Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this video, Scott Hanselman shows how easy it is to sign up for a free trial of Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: (Duration: 1:58)
trans-unit.target: (Duration: 1:58)

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET web application
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET web application

trans-unit.source: Your first step is to create a web project in Visual Studio and a web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Your first step is to create a web project in Visual Studio and a web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: When that's done, you'll deploy the project to the web app to make it available on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: When that's done, you'll deploy the project to the web app to make it available on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: The diagram illustrates what you're doing in the create and deploy steps.
trans-unit.target: The diagram illustrates what you're doing in the create and deploy steps.

trans-unit.source: Create and deploy
trans-unit.target: Create and deploy

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: If you use Visual Studio 2013, the screens will be slightly different from the screenshots, but the procedures are essentially the same.
trans-unit.target: If you use Visual Studio 2013, the screens will be slightly different from the screenshots, but the procedures are essentially the same.

trans-unit.source: From the **File** menu, click **New > Project**.
trans-unit.target: From the **File** menu, click **New > Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the **New Project** dialog box, click **C# > Web > ASP.NET Web Application**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New Project** dialog box, click **C# > Web > ASP.NET Web Application**.

trans-unit.source: If you prefer, you can choose **Visual Basic**.
trans-unit.target: If you prefer, you can choose **Visual Basic**.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that **.NET Framework 4.5.2** is selected as the target framework.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that **.NET Framework 4.5.2** is selected as the target framework.

trans-unit.source: [Azure Application Insights](app-insights-overview.md) monitors your web app for availability, performance, and usage.
trans-unit.target: [Azure Application Insights](app-insights-overview.md) monitors your web app for availability, performance, and usage.

trans-unit.source: Clear the **Add Application Insights to Project** check box if you don't want to try it.
trans-unit.target: Clear the **Add Application Insights to Project** check box if you don't want to try it.

trans-unit.source: Name the application **MyExample**.
trans-unit.target: Name the application **MyExample**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: New Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, select the **MVC** template.
trans-unit.target: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, select the **MVC** template.

trans-unit.source: [MVC](http://www.asp.net/mvc) is an ASP.NET framework for developing web apps.
trans-unit.target: [MVC](http://www.asp.net/mvc) is an ASP.NET framework for developing web apps.

trans-unit.source: Click **Change Authentication**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Change Authentication**.

trans-unit.source: New ASP.NET Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New ASP.NET Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: In the **Change Authentication** dialog box, click **No Authentication**, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Change Authentication** dialog box, click **No Authentication**, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: No Authentication
trans-unit.target: No Authentication

trans-unit.source: The sample application that you're creating won't enable users to log in.
trans-unit.target: The sample application that you're creating won't enable users to log in.

trans-unit.source: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that implements authentication and authorization.
trans-unit.target: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that implements authentication and authorization.

trans-unit.source: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, leave the settings under **Microsoft Azure** unchanged, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, leave the settings under **Microsoft Azure** unchanged, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: New ASP.NET Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New ASP.NET Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: The default settings specify that Visual Studio will create an Azure web app for your web project.
trans-unit.target: The default settings specify that Visual Studio will create an Azure web app for your web project.

trans-unit.source: In the next section of the tutorial, you'll deploy the web project to the newly created web app.
trans-unit.target: In the next section of the tutorial, you'll deploy the web project to the newly created web app.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already signed in to Azure, Visual Studio prompts you to do so.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already signed in to Azure, Visual Studio prompts you to do so.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with the ID and password of the account that you use to manage your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with the ID and password of the account that you use to manage your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: When you're signed in, the **Configure Microsoft Azure Web App Settings** dialog box asks you what resources you want to create.
trans-unit.target: When you're signed in, the **Configure Microsoft Azure Web App Settings** dialog box asks you what resources you want to create.

trans-unit.source: Signed in to Azure
trans-unit.target: Signed in to Azure

trans-unit.source: In the **Configure Microsoft Azure Web App Settings** dialog box, enter a **Web App name** that is unique in the *azurewebsites.net* domain.
trans-unit.target: In the **Configure Microsoft Azure Web App Settings** dialog box, enter a **Web App name** that is unique in the *azurewebsites.net* domain.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can name it MyExample with numbers to the right to make it unique, such as MyExample810.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can name it MyExample with numbers to the right to make it unique, such as MyExample810.

trans-unit.source: If a default web name is created for you, it will be unique and you can use that.
trans-unit.target: If a default web name is created for you, it will be unique and you can use that.

trans-unit.source: If someone else has already used the name that you enter, you'll see a red exclamation mark to the right instead of a green check mark, and you'll need to enter a different name.
trans-unit.target: If someone else has already used the name that you enter, you'll see a red exclamation mark to the right instead of a green check mark, and you'll need to enter a different name.

trans-unit.source: Azure will use this name as the prefix for your application's URL.
trans-unit.target: Azure will use this name as the prefix for your application's URL.

trans-unit.source: The complete URL will consist of this name plus *.azurewebsites.net* (as shown next to the **Web App name** text box).
trans-unit.target: The complete URL will consist of this name plus *.azurewebsites.net* (as shown next to the **Web App name** text box).

trans-unit.source: For example, if the name is `MyExample810`, the URL will be `MyExample810.azurewebsites.net`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the name is `MyExample810`, the URL will be `MyExample810.azurewebsites.net`.

trans-unit.source: The URL has to be unique.
trans-unit.target: The URL has to be unique.

trans-unit.source: In the **App Service plan** drop-down, select **Create new App Service plan**.
trans-unit.target: In the **App Service plan** drop-down, select **Create new App Service plan**.

trans-unit.source: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section has links to information about App Service plans.
trans-unit.target: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section has links to information about App Service plans.

trans-unit.source: Enter **MyExamplePlan**, or another name if you prefer, for the plan name.
trans-unit.target: Enter **MyExamplePlan**, or another name if you prefer, for the plan name.

trans-unit.source: In the **Resource group** drop-down, select **Create new resource group**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Resource group** drop-down, select **Create new resource group**.

trans-unit.source: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section has links to information about resource groups.
trans-unit.target: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section has links to information about resource groups.

trans-unit.source: Enter **MyExampleGroup**, or another name if you prefer, for the resource group name.
trans-unit.target: Enter **MyExampleGroup**, or another name if you prefer, for the resource group name.

trans-unit.source: In the **Region** drop-down list, choose the location that is closest to you.
trans-unit.target: In the **Region** drop-down list, choose the location that is closest to you.

trans-unit.source: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter your web app will run in.
trans-unit.target: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter your web app will run in.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you can select any region and it won't make a noticeable difference.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you can select any region and it won't make a noticeable difference.

trans-unit.source: But for a production web app, you want your web server to be as close as possible to the browsers that are accessing your site in order to minimize [latency](http://www.bing.com/search?q=web%20latency%20introduction&qs=n&form=QBRE&pq=web%20latency%20introduction&sc=1-24&sp=-1&sk=&cvid=eefff99dfc864d25a75a83740f1e0090).
trans-unit.target: But for a production web app, you want your web server to be as close as possible to the browsers that are accessing your site in order to minimize [latency](http://www.bing.com/search?q=web%20latency%20introduction&qs=n&form=QBRE&pq=web%20latency%20introduction&sc=1-24&sp=-1&sk=&cvid=eefff99dfc864d25a75a83740f1e0090).

trans-unit.source: Leave the database field unchanged.
trans-unit.target: Leave the database field unchanged.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you aren't using a database.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you aren't using a database.

trans-unit.source: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that shows how to use a database.
trans-unit.target: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that shows how to use a database.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds, Visual Studio creates the web project in the folder that you specified, and it creates the web app in the Azure region that you specified.
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds, Visual Studio creates the web project in the folder that you specified, and it creates the web app in the Azure region that you specified.

trans-unit.source: The **Solution Explorer** window shows the files and folders in the new project.
trans-unit.target: The **Solution Explorer** window shows the files and folders in the new project.

trans-unit.source: Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: The **Azure App Service Activity** window shows that the web app has been created.
trans-unit.target: The **Azure App Service Activity** window shows that the web app has been created.

trans-unit.source: Web app created
trans-unit.target: Web app created

trans-unit.source: And you can see the web app in **Server Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: And you can see the web app in **Server Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: Web app created
trans-unit.target: Web app created

trans-unit.source: Deploy the application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the application to Azure

trans-unit.source: In the **Azure App Service Activity** window, click **Publish MyExample to this Web App now**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Azure App Service Activity** window, click **Publish MyExample to this Web App now**.

trans-unit.source: Web app created
trans-unit.target: Web app created

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds, the **Publish Web** wizard appears.
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds, the **Publish Web** wizard appears.

trans-unit.source: Settings that Visual Studio needs to deploy your project to Azure have been saved in a *publish profile*.
trans-unit.target: Settings that Visual Studio needs to deploy your project to Azure have been saved in a *publish profile*.

trans-unit.source: You can use the wizard to review and change those settings.
trans-unit.target: You can use the wizard to review and change those settings.

trans-unit.source: On the **Connection** tab of the **Publish Web** wizard, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Connection** tab of the **Publish Web** wizard, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides all the settings you need to deploy to your Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides all the settings you need to deploy to your Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: Successfully validated connection
trans-unit.target: Successfully validated connection

trans-unit.source: On the **Settings** tab, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Settings** tab, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: You can accept the default values for **Configuration** and **File Publish Options**.
trans-unit.target: You can accept the default values for **Configuration** and **File Publish Options**.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **Configuration** drop-down to deploy a Debug build for remote debugging.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **Configuration** drop-down to deploy a Debug build for remote debugging.

trans-unit.source: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that shows how to run Visual Studio in debug mode remotely.
trans-unit.target: The [Next steps](#next-steps) section links to a tutorial that shows how to run Visual Studio in debug mode remotely.

trans-unit.source: Settings tab
trans-unit.target: Settings tab

trans-unit.source: On the **Preview** tab, click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Preview** tab, click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: If you want to see what files will be copied to Azure, you can click **Start Preview** before clicking **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: If you want to see what files will be copied to Azure, you can click **Start Preview** before clicking **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio begins the process of copying the files to the Azure server.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio begins the process of copying the files to the Azure server.

trans-unit.source: The **Output** and **Azure App Service Activity** windows show what deployment actions were taken and report successful completion of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: The **Output** and **Azure App Service Activity** windows show what deployment actions were taken and report successful completion of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Output window reporting successful deployment
trans-unit.target: Output window reporting successful deployment

trans-unit.source: Upon successful deployment, the default browser automatically opens to the URL of the deployed web app, and the application that you created is now running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Upon successful deployment, the default browser automatically opens to the URL of the deployed web app, and the application that you created is now running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The URL in the browser address bar shows that the web app is loaded from the Internet.
trans-unit.target: The URL in the browser address bar shows that the web app is loaded from the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Web app running in Azure
trans-unit.target: Web app running in Azure

trans-unit.source: Close the browser.
trans-unit.target: Close the browser.

trans-unit.source: Make a change and redeploy
trans-unit.target: Make a change and redeploy

trans-unit.source: This section of the tutorial is optional.
trans-unit.target: This section of the tutorial is optional.

trans-unit.source: What you'll do is change the **h1** heading of the home page, run the project locally on your development computer to verify the change, and then deploy the change to Azure.
trans-unit.target: What you'll do is change the **h1** heading of the home page, run the project locally on your development computer to verify the change, and then deploy the change to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Open the **Views/Home/Index.cshtml** or **.vbhtml** file in **Solution Explorer**, change the **h1** heading from "ASP.NET" to "ASP.NET and Azure", and save the file.
trans-unit.target: Open the **Views/Home/Index.cshtml** or **.vbhtml** file in **Solution Explorer**, change the **h1** heading from "ASP.NET" to "ASP.NET and Azure", and save the file.

trans-unit.source: MVC index.cshtml
trans-unit.target: MVC index.cshtml

trans-unit.source: MVC h1 change
trans-unit.target: MVC h1 change

trans-unit.source: Press Ctrl+F5 to see the updated heading by running the web app on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Press Ctrl+F5 to see the updated heading by running the web app on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Web app running locally
trans-unit.target: Web app running locally

trans-unit.source: The `localhost` URL shows that it's running on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: The `localhost` URL shows that it's running on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: By default it's running in IIS Express, which is a lightweight version of IIS that's designed for use during web application development.
trans-unit.target: By default it's running in IIS Express, which is a lightweight version of IIS that's designed for use during web application development.

trans-unit.source: Close the browser.
trans-unit.target: Close the browser.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, right-click the project, and choose **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, right-click the project, and choose **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Choose Publish
trans-unit.target: Choose Publish

trans-unit.source: The **Preview** tab of the **Publish Web** wizard appears.
trans-unit.target: The **Preview** tab of the **Publish Web** wizard appears.

trans-unit.source: If you needed to change any publish settings, you could choose a different tab, but now all you want to do is redeploy with the same settings.
trans-unit.target: If you needed to change any publish settings, you could choose a different tab, but now all you want to do is redeploy with the same settings.

trans-unit.source: In the **Publish Web** wizard, click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Publish Web** wizard, click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish
trans-unit.target: Click Publish

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio deploys the project to Azure and opens the web app in the default browser.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio deploys the project to Azure and opens the web app in the default browser.

trans-unit.source: Changed web app deployed
trans-unit.target: Changed web app deployed

trans-unit.source: **Tip:** You can enable the **Web One Click Publish** toolbar for even quicker deployment.
trans-unit.target: **Tip:** You can enable the **Web One Click Publish** toolbar for even quicker deployment.

trans-unit.source: Click **View > Toolbars**, and then select **Web One Click Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **View > Toolbars**, and then select **Web One Click Publish**.

trans-unit.source: You can use the toolbar to select a profile, click a button to publish, or click a button to open the **Publish Web** wizard.
trans-unit.target: You can use the toolbar to select a profile, click a button to publish, or click a button to open the **Publish Web** wizard.

trans-unit.source: Web One Click Publish Toolbar
trans-unit.target: Web One Click Publish Toolbar

trans-unit.source: Monitor and manage the web app in the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Monitor and manage the web app in the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: The [Azure portal](/services/management-portal/) is a web interface that you can use to manage and monitor your Azure services, such as the web app that you just created.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure portal](/services/management-portal/) is a web interface that you can use to manage and monitor your Azure services, such as the web app that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In this section of the tutorial, you look at some of what you can do in the portal.
trans-unit.target: In this section of the tutorial, you look at some of what you can do in the portal.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, go to [https://portal.azure.com](https://portal.azure.com), and sign in with your Azure credentials.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, go to [https://portal.azure.com](https://portal.azure.com), and sign in with your Azure credentials.

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse All > Web Apps**, and then click the name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse All > Web Apps**, and then click the name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: The **Web app** blade displays an overview of settings and usage statistics for your web app.
trans-unit.target: The **Web app** blade displays an overview of settings and usage statistics for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Web app blade
trans-unit.target: Web app blade

trans-unit.source: At this point, your web app hasn't had much traffic and may not show anything in the graph.
trans-unit.target: At this point, your web app hasn't had much traffic and may not show anything in the graph.

trans-unit.source: If you browse to your application, refresh the page a few times, and then refresh the portal page, you'll see some statistics show up.
trans-unit.target: If you browse to your application, refresh the page a few times, and then refresh the portal page, you'll see some statistics show up.

trans-unit.source: Click **Settings** to see more options for configuring your web app.
trans-unit.target: Click **Settings** to see more options for configuring your web app.

trans-unit.source: You see a list of types of settings.
trans-unit.target: You see a list of types of settings.

trans-unit.source: Click **Application settings** to see an example of the kinds of settings that you can configure in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click **Application settings** to see an example of the kinds of settings that you can configure in the portal.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can control the .NET version that's used for the web app, enable features such as [WebSockets](/blog/2013/11/14/introduction-to-websockets-on-windows-azure-web-sites/), and set [connection string values](/blog/2013/07/17/windows-azure-web-sites-how-application-strings-and-connection-strings-work/).
trans-unit.target: For example, you can control the .NET version that's used for the web app, enable features such as [WebSockets](/blog/2013/11/14/introduction-to-websockets-on-windows-azure-web-sites/), and set [connection string values](/blog/2013/07/17/windows-azure-web-sites-how-application-strings-and-connection-strings-work/).

trans-unit.source: Portal web app configure tab
trans-unit.target: Portal web app configure tab

trans-unit.source: These are just a few of the portal's features.
trans-unit.target: These are just a few of the portal's features.

trans-unit.source: You can create new web apps, delete existing web apps, stop and restart web apps, and manage other kinds of Azure services, such as databases and virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: You can create new web apps, delete existing web apps, stop and restart web apps, and manage other kinds of Azure services, such as databases and virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you've seen how to create a simple web application and deploy it to an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you've seen how to create a simple web application and deploy it to an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: Here are some related topics and resources for learning more about web apps in Azure App Service:
trans-unit.target: Here are some related topics and resources for learning more about web apps in Azure App Service:

trans-unit.source: Other ways to deploy a web project
trans-unit.target: Other ways to deploy a web project

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you saw the quickest way to create a web app and deploy it all in one operation.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you saw the quickest way to create a web app and deploy it all in one operation.

trans-unit.source: For an overview of other ways to deploy, by using Visual Studio or by [automating deployment](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/continuous-integration-and-continuous-delivery) from a [source control system](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/source-control), see [How to deploy an Azure web app](web-sites-deploy.md).
trans-unit.target: For an overview of other ways to deploy, by using Visual Studio or by [automating deployment](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/continuous-integration-and-continuous-delivery) from a [source control system](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/source-control), see [How to deploy an Azure web app](web-sites-deploy.md).

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio can also generate Windows PowerShell scripts that you can use to automate deployment.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio can also generate Windows PowerShell scripts that you can use to automate deployment.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Automate Everything (Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure)](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/automate-everything).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Automate Everything (Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure)](http://www.asp.net/aspnet/overview/developing-apps-with-windows-azure/building-real-world-cloud-apps-with-windows-azure/automate-everything).

trans-unit.source: How to manage a web app in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: How to manage a web app in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: For information about web app management functions that you can do in **Server Explorer**, see [Troubleshooting Azure web apps in Visual Studio](web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about web app management functions that you can do in **Server Explorer**, see [Troubleshooting Azure web apps in Visual Studio](web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: How to troubleshoot a web app
trans-unit.target: How to troubleshoot a web app

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides features that make it easy to view Azure logs as they are generated in real time.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides features that make it easy to view Azure logs as they are generated in real time.

trans-unit.source: You can also run in debug mode remotely in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can also run in debug mode remotely in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Troubleshooting Azure web apps in Visual Studio](web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Troubleshooting Azure web apps in Visual Studio](web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: How to add database and authorization functionality
trans-unit.target: How to add database and authorization functionality

trans-unit.source: For a tutorial that shows how to access a database and restrict some application functions to authorized users, see [Deploy a secure ASP.NET MVC app with membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to an Azure web app](/develop/net/tutorials/web-site-with-sql-database/).
trans-unit.target: For a tutorial that shows how to access a database and restrict some application functions to authorized users, see [Deploy a secure ASP.NET MVC app with membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to an Azure web app](/develop/net/tutorials/web-site-with-sql-database/).

trans-unit.source: How to add a custom domain name and SSL
trans-unit.target: How to add a custom domain name and SSL

trans-unit.source: For information about how to use SSL and your own domain (for example, www.contoso.com instead of contoso.azurewebsites.net), see the following resources:
trans-unit.target: For information about how to use SSL and your own domain (for example, www.contoso.com instead of contoso.azurewebsites.net), see the following resources:

trans-unit.source: Configure a custom domain name in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Configure a custom domain name in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Enable HTTPS for an Azure website
trans-unit.target: Enable HTTPS for an Azure website

trans-unit.source: How to avoid wake-up wait time after idle time-outs
trans-unit.target: How to avoid wake-up wait time after idle time-outs

trans-unit.source: By default, web apps are unloaded if they have been idle for some period of time.
trans-unit.target: By default, web apps are unloaded if they have been idle for some period of time.

trans-unit.source: The first request after a web app has been unloaded has to wait for the web app to be reloaded.
trans-unit.target: The first request after a web app has been unloaded has to wait for the web app to be reloaded.

trans-unit.source: To avoid that wait time, you can enable the Always On feature.
trans-unit.target: To avoid that wait time, you can enable the Always On feature.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the configuration options in [How to configure web apps](web-sites-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the configuration options in [How to configure web apps](web-sites-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: How to add real-time features such as chat
trans-unit.target: How to add real-time features such as chat

trans-unit.source: If your web app will include real-time features (such as a chat service, a game, or a stock ticker), you can get the best performance by using [ASP.NET SignalR](http://www.asp.net/signalr) with the [WebSockets](/blog/2013/11/14/introduction-to-websockets-on-windows-azure-web-sites/) transport method.
trans-unit.target: If your web app will include real-time features (such as a chat service, a game, or a stock ticker), you can get the best performance by using [ASP.NET SignalR](http://www.asp.net/signalr) with the [WebSockets](/blog/2013/11/14/introduction-to-websockets-on-windows-azure-web-sites/) transport method.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Using SignalR with Azure web apps](http://www.asp.net/signalr/overview/signalr-20/getting-started-with-signalr-20/using-signalr-with-windows-azure-web-sites).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Using SignalR with Azure web apps](http://www.asp.net/signalr/overview/signalr-20/getting-started-with-signalr-20/using-signalr-with-windows-azure-web-sites).

trans-unit.source: How to choose between App Service, Azure Cloud Services, and Azure Virtual Machines for web applications
trans-unit.target: How to choose between App Service, Azure Cloud Services, and Azure Virtual Machines for web applications

trans-unit.source: In Azure, you can run web applications in App Service Web Apps as shown in this tutorial, or in Cloud Services or in Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: In Azure, you can run web applications in App Service Web Apps as shown in this tutorial, or in Cloud Services or in Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure web apps, cloud services, and VMs: When to use which?](/manage/services/web-sites/choose-web-app-service/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure web apps, cloud services, and VMs: When to use which?](/manage/services/web-sites/choose-web-app-service/).

trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service, see [Azure App Service and existing Azure services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714).
